JSimHelp.item: Diagram of all models, datasets, parameter sets, plot pages, etc. contained in this project. Allows loading and saving project files from disk and pasting of content between projects.

One JSim model within this project. A model is a set of numeric calculations specified in JSim Mathematical Modeling Language (MML). Once a model is successfully compiled, it may be run creating output data that may be graphed in plot pages or used in other ways.
A project data set, containing fixed numeric data loaded from files or previous model runs.

One plot page within this project. Plot pages contain one or more plots, arranged in columns and rows. Each plot may contain multiple data curves drawn from either model outputs or fixed project data sets.
Run-time messages for this JSim session.
Free-form text notes page.
Manage a project file.
Click on a piece of the project in the project sub-tree. Then manage the piece of the project.
Add model(s), data, plot pages, notes and image sets to the project-subtree
Manages the Message area as a note file.
erase (erases ALL messages) in the message area
Open and load an existing project file. Project files have suffix .proj
Create a new project. Causes a new project window to appear. May overlay project which is already open. Different projects do not share access to each others elements.
Save this project. If project has never been saved (named) this becomes Save as ...
Save this project, naming it. Including the suffix .proj is optional.
Not currently implemented.
Close the project. If this is the only project open, JSim also terminates. User asked if saving changes to project required.
Terminates JSim. User asked if saving changes to project required.
Removes an element of the project tree. Select (click) an element of the project. Then select cut from the Edit menu. Action undo is to paste it back.
Copy a project element. Select (click) an element of the project. Then select copy from the Edit menu. Element will be copied and its name extended.
Create a copy of an existing project element and extend its name.
Rename a project element. Duplicate names are rejected. Ctrl-r
Import a model file (has .mod suffix). A project may contain more than one model. Each model has its separate controls.
Load an external data file into the project as a data set. A half-dozen (or so) external formats are importable including TAC and spread-sheet compatible columnar data.
Open a blank source page for composing a model. Model is given default name. To change name select model from project tree and use Edit/rename.
Add a new plot page. New plot page and tab appear on right side of Jsim window. Default name assigned.
A new notes page is opened and given a default name.
An image set is created and given a default name. The image set viewer is not yet implemented.
JSim documentation is provided on-line at http://physiome.org/jsim Follow the links to JSim documentation.

F1 and shift-F1 keys control context sensitive help. F1 enables hover help which pops up after 1.5 seconds without mouse motion. shift-F1 enables fast help which pops up immediately. Hover help is enabled by default.
JSim is a Java based simulation system intended for biomedical applications. Downloads are available at http://physiome.org/jsim Follow the links to JSim download.

JSim is distributed by the National Simulation Resource for Transport Metabolism and Exchange (NSR). NSR creates, collects and disseminates material of interest to biological modelers. For further information see http://nsr.bioeng.washington.edu
A new notes page is created and added to the project tree with a default name. The contents of the Message page are copied to the notes page.
The contents of the message page are exported to a file named by the user.
The contents of the message page are printed.
Go to a specified line number in the message page.
find the indicated word(s) in the Message page. Case sensitive. Begins at current position and wraps around the page.
find next occurrence of indicated word(s) entered under find.
Erase ALL of the Message page. No Undo.
This function is a single pulse or a train of pulses.
This function is a double pulse or mixed pulse train. It is similar to Pulse1 with two sets of parameters, but only one offset parameter.
This function is a triple pulse or mixed pulse train. It is similar to Pulse2, but has three sets of parameters, but only one offset parameter.
Use this pulse generator when NOT in loop mode and at a fixed time interval the amplitude of a given pulse is incremented by a constant. Provides 3 levels of looping on amplitudes IN A SINGLE RUN.
This function is a power function ramp of the form: Value=offset+amplitude* [(startTime-t)/(tdur)]^exponent when t is greater than startTime and less than or equal to duration.
This function is generates a train of square waves and can be used to generate a single pulse. It's usage overlaps with Pulse1, but has some significant differences as noted below.
This function is generates a train of sawtooths. It's parameters are the same as the Square Wave where shapeFactor controls the fraction of the period the sawtooth is rising and falling.
This function generates a train of sine waves. It has all but one of the parameters used for the square and sawtooth wave trains (doesn't use ShapeFactor.)
This function generates an exponential PDF which abruptly rises from zero to its maximum value, then decays.
This function generates a Gaussian PDF.

This function generates a Lagged Normal PDF. It is similar to a Gaussian, but with positive skewness (skewness of a Gaussian PDF is zero.) CAVEATS: 2 .lt. skewn .le. 0. When skewn = 0, the Gaussian PDF will be used and no Linear upslope. When skewn approaches 2, the Exponential PDF will be used.
This function is a combination of a LagNormal PDF to which is joined a longtailed function which consists of a sum of decaying exponentials.

This function generates a gamma variate PDF. It has some similarities to the LagNormal PDF. CAVEATS: skewn is defaulted from a minimum of 0.267 to a maximum of 1.999 if it exceeds these limits. The actual RD used is the smaller of RD and skewn/2.01.

This function generates a Poisson-like PDF using a scaled Poisson equation in which lambda is allowed to vary continuously and n is fixed. This curve represents the transport of a tracer through n identical well mixed compartments.
This function generates a first traversal of a random walk PDF. CAVEAT: The actual skewness used is the maximum of skewn and 3.001*RD.
This function is an interpolation of a Data Curve. It is imported as a file using the Project tab, then the Add button, selecting Import data file (.tac +).
Choose a function generator
The start time, when the function has the value "amplitude+offset."
Duration of the pulse.
Value added to offset during the duration of the pulse.
The offset or base value for the function for all time.
If timeToRepeat is greater than zero, the signal generated from time equals 0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval.
The start time of the first pulse. The function has the value "p1Amplitude+offset+contribution from the second pulse."
Duration of the first pulse.
Value added to p1offset during the duration of the pulse.
The offset or base value for the function for all time.

If p1TimeToRepeat is greater than zero, the first pulse signal gener- ated from time equals 0 to p1TimeToRepeat is repeated every p1TimeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of mixed pulses.
The start time of the second pulse, when the function has the value "p2Amplitude+contribution of the first pulse."
Duration of the second pulse.
Value added to the function during the duration of the second pulse.

If p2TimeToRepeat is greater than zero, the second pulse generated during time equals 0 to p2TimeToRepeat is repeated every p2TimeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of mixed pulses.
The start time of the first pulse. The function has the value "p1Amplitude+offset+contribution from the second and third pulses."
Duration of the first pulse.
Value added to p1offset during the duration of the pulse.
The offset or base value for the function for all time.

If p1TimeToRepeat is greater than zero, the first pulse signal gener- ated from time equals 0 to p1TimeToRepeat is repeated every p1TimeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of mixed pulses.
The start time of the second pulse, when the function has the value "p2Amplitude+contribution of the first and third pulses."
Duration of the second pulse.
Value added to the function during the duration of the second pulse.

If p2TimeToRepeat is greater than zero, the second pulse generated during time equals 0 to p2TimeToRepeat is repeated every p2TimeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of mixed pulses.
The start time of the third pulse, when the function has the value "p3Amplitude+contribution of the first and second pulses."
Duration of the third pulse.
Value added to the function during the duration of the third pulse.

If p3TimeToRepeat is greater than zero, the third pulse generated during time equals 0 to p3TimeToRepeat is repeated every p3TimeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of mixed pulses.
The offset or base value for the function for all time.
Usage is different here. This is the amount of time elapsed to trigger the next innermost loop of the pulse generator.
The start time of the outermost pulse cycle.
Duration of the outermost pulse.
Initial amplitude of the outermost pulse.
The number of loops or cycles of the outermost pulse. 0 and 1 have same effect.
Amplitude increment of the outermost loop or cycle.
The start time of the centermost pulse cycle.
Duration of the centermost pulse.
Initial amplitude of the centermost pulse.
The number of loops or cycles of the centermost pulse. 0 and 1 have same effect.
Amplitude increment of the centermost loop or cycle.
The start time of the innermost pulse cycle.
Duration of the innermost pulse.
Initial amplitude of the innermost pulse.
The number of loops or cycles of the innermost pulse.
Amplitude increment of the innermost loop or cycle. 0 and 1 have same effect.
Start time of the ramp.
Duration of the ramp.
Height of ramp when exponent greater than or equal to zero. Amplitude may be negative.
The offset or base value for the function during the duration off the ramp (similar to usage in square wave, but different from usage in Pulse1, Pulse2, and Pulse3.
The exponent for the power function of the ramp. Negative exponents can cause large magnitudes at beginning of ramp. Value of zero resembles Pulse1 but treatment off offset is different.
If timeToRepeat is greater than zero, the signal generated from time equals 0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of ramps.
The start time, when the Square Wave train begins.
Duration of the square wave train.
Value = amplitude+offset during duration when square wave train is "on"
The offset or base value for the function during duration when square wave train is in "off" mode. This is different from the offset in Pulse1, Pulse2, and Pulse3 which is present for all time.

1 for "on" for entire period (value= amplitude+offset), 0 for "off" for entire period (value=offset), 0.25 "on" for the first quarter of the period followed by "off" for the last three quarters of the period. Any value less the zero will be defaulted to zero. Any value greater than 1 will be defaulted to 1.
fraction of period to shift wave train. All integer values have same effect (specifically, no effect).
The period of the square wave.

If timeToRepeat is greater than zero, the signal generated from time equals 0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of square wave trains.
The start time, when the sawtooth train begins.
Duration of the sawtooth train.
Value = amplitude* (startTime-t)/tdur +offset during period when sawtooth is rising.
The offset or base value for the function during duration of sawtooth.

1 for sawtooth always rising over entire period, 0 for always falling over entire period, 0.25 sawtooth rises in maximum value in 1st quarter of period, falls to offset value over last three quarters of period. A value less the zero will be defaulted to zero. Any value greater than 1 will be defaulted to 1.
Fraction of period to shift wave train. All integer values have same effect (specifically, no effect).
The period of the square wave.

If timeToRepeat is greater than zero, the signal generated from time equals 0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of sawtooth wave trains.
The start time, when the sine train begins.
Duration of the sine train.
Amplitude of the sine wave.
The offset or base value for the function during duration.
Fraction of period to shift sine wave. All integer values have same effect (specifically, no effect). A value of -0.25 makes this a cosine wave.
Period of 1 cycle of the sine wave.

If timeToRepeat is greater than zero, the signal generated from time equals 0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. Hence, this function can be used to generate a train of sine wave trains.

The area of the PDF function. If less than or equal to zero, it is defaulted to a value of 1. Formally it is the integral from start time (usually take to be zero) to infinity of PDF(t)*dt where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is a function of the independent variable. Area is used to scale the PDF so it is an appropriate model input.

The mean transit time of the PDF relative to the start time, t.min, where t is the independent realDomain variable. It is approximately the difference between the start time and when the peak of the PDF occurs. Formally, it is the integral from start time to infinity of PDF(t)*t*dt/area where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is the PDF as a function of the independent variable

Relative dispersion of the PDF is the standard deviation of the PDF divided by the mean transit time. Formally, it is the square root of the integral from the start time (usually taken to be zero) to infinity (usually taken to be some large finite time) of PDF(t)*(t-tMean)*(t-tMean)*dt, all of which is divided by tMean.
The skewness of the PDF.

Fraction of the peak or maximum value of a PDF after which the PDF is truncated (set to zero). Normally defaulted to 1.0E-06. It causes truncation only after the peak. Usage is different for the Longtail PDF.
If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of PDF pulses.

The area of the PDFfunction. If less than or equal to zero, it is defaulted to a value of 1. Formally it is the integral from start time (usually take to be zero) to infinity of PDF(t)*dt where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is a function of the independent variable. Area is used to scale the PDF so it is an appropriate model input.

The mean transit time of the PDF relative to the start time, t.min, where t is the independent realDomain variable. It is approximately the difference between the start time and when the peak of the PDF occurs. Formally, it is the integral from start time to infinity of PDF(t)*t*dt/area where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is the PDF as a function of the independent variable

Relative dispersion of the PDF is the standard deviation of the PDF divided by the mean transit time. Formally, it is the square root of the integral from the start time (usually taken to be zero) to infinity (usually taken to be some large finite time) of PDF(t)*(t-tMean)*(t-tMean)*dt, all of which is divided by tMean.

Fraction of the peak or maximum value of a PDF after which the PDF is truncated (set to zero). Normally defaulted to 1.0E-06. It causes truncation only after the peak. Usage is different for the Longtail PDF.
If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of PDF pulses.

The area of the PDF function. If less than or equal to zero, it is defaulted to a value of 1. Formally it is the integral from start time (usually take to be zero) to infinity of PDF(t)*dt where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is a function of the independent variable. Area is used to scale the PDF so it is an appropriate model input.

The mean transit time of the PDF relative to the start time, t.min, where t is the independent realDomain variable. It is approximately the difference between the start time and when the peak of the PDF occurs. Formally, it is the integral from start time to infinity of PDF(t)*t*dt/area where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is the PDF as a function of the independent variable

Relative dispersion of the PDF is the standard deviation of the PDF divided by the mean transit time. Formally, it is the square root of the integral from the start time (usually taken to be zero) to infinity (usually taken to be some large finite time) of PDF(t)*(t-tMean)*(t-tMean)*dt, all of which is divided by tMean.

Fraction of the peak or maximum value of a PDF after which the PDF is truncated (set to zero). Normally defaulted to 1.0E-06. It causes truncation only after the peak. Usage is different for the Longtail PDF.
If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of PDF pulses.

The area of the PDF function. If less than or equal to zero, it is defaulted to a value of 1. Formally it is the integral from start time (usually take to be zero) to infinity of PDF(t)*dt where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is a function of the independent variable. Area is used to scale the PDF so it is an appropriate model input.

The mean transit time of the PDF relative to the start time, t.min, where t is the independent realDomain variable. It is approximately the difference between the start time and when the peak of the PDF occurs. Formally, it is the integral from start time to infinity of PDF(t)*t*dt/area where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is the PDF as a function of the independent variable

Relative dispersion of the PDF is the standard deviation of the PDF divided by the mean transit time. Formally, it is the square root of the integral from the start time (usually taken to be zero) to infinity (usually taken to be some large finite time) of PDF(t)*(t-tMean)*(t-tMean)*dt, all of which is divided by tMean.
The skewness of the PDF. CAVEATS 2 .lt. skewn .le. 0. When skewn = 0, the Gaussian PDF will be used and no Linear upslope. When skewn approaches 2, the "Exponential" PDF will be used.

Fraction of the peak or maximum value of a PDF after which the PDF is truncated (set to zero). Normally defaulted to 1.0E-06. It causes truncation only after the peak. Usage is different for the Longtail PDF.
If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of PDF pulses.
Choice of Regular or Linear (early part of rise of PDF replaced by linear approximation.

The area of the PDF function. If less than or equal to zero, it is defaulted to a value of 1. Formally it is the integral from start time (usually take to be zero) to infinity of PDF(t)*dt where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is a function of the independent variable. Area is used to scale the PDF so it is an appropriate model input.

The mean transit time of the PDF relative to the start time, t.min, where t is the independent realDomain variable. It is approximately the difference between the start time and when the peak of the PDF occurs. Formally, it is the integral from start time to infinity of PDF(t)*t*dt/area where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is the PDF as a function of the independent variable

Formally, it is the square root of the integral from the start time (usually taken to be zero) to infinity (usually taken to be some large finite time) of PDF(t)*(t-tMean)*(t-tMean)*dt, all of which is divided by tMean. CAVEAT: The actual RD used is the smaller of RD and skewn/2.01.
The skewness of the PDF. CAVEAT: skewn is defaulted from a minimum of 0.267 to a maximum of 1.999 if it exceeds these limits. The actual RD used is the smaller of RD and skewn/2.01.

Fraction of the peak or maximum value of a PDF after which the PDF is truncated (set to zero). Normally defaulted to 1.0E-06. It causes truncation only after the peak. Usage is different for the Longtail PDF.
If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of PDF pulses.

CAVEAT: The actual skewness used is the maximum of skewn and 3.001*rd.
The skewness of the PDF. CAVEAT: The actual skewness used is the maximum of skewn and 3.001*rd.

If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of PDF pulses.
The dimension of the Data object. Currently, only one dimensional data is supported.
A choice button listing tac files.
The curve designation in the tac file.

Number of Internal Steps

Maximum Internal Step Size

Initial Order
Starting Value of Newton Iterations
How often Jacobian should be calculated

Relative Upper Bound for not Changing Step Size

Relative Upper Bound for Step Selection

High Threshold of Contractivity Factor for Decreasing Order
Relative Upper Bound for Decreasing Order
Relative Lower Bound for Decreasing Order

Order of Polynomial

Algorithm for bounded problems
Min required RMS error
Max number of function calls per variable
Max number of iterations per variable
Initial parameter step
Relative error
Set storage encoding for this data set within a project file.
This encoding is supported by all JSim version back to 1.6.00. However, it is very inefficient for large data sets.
This encoding is supported by only by JSim versions 1.6.47 and above. However, it is very efficient for large data sets.
Display the graph
Display the data used for plotting.
Manage the plot page and the data being plotted.
Number of rows of plots for plot page. Plots are numbered sequentially from left to right, top to bottom.
Number of columns of plots for plot page. Plots are numbered sequentially from left to right, top to bottom.
Create a duplicate of this plot page and give it a default name.
Delete this plot page.
Store the data in a text format as a project dataset.
Save this data set as a file.
Print the graph(s) displayed on the plot page.
Show animation configuration dialog.

Axis bounds slider. Drag center to adjust axis min and min. Double-click center for full data scale. Drag left or right tail to min or max separately. Double-click tails to move one range up or down. Only active when plot has data and autoscale off.
Start animation if idle. Stop animation if animation running or paused
Cancel animation dialog if idle. Pause animation if animation running. Resume animation if animation paused.
Check box for logarithmic axis. Uncheck box for linear axis.
Check box for Autoscaling of axis. Uncheck box for user-selected scaling of axis using Min and Max boxes on the right.
Set the minimum value for axis. Used with Autoscale box unchecked.
Set the maximum value for axis. Used with Autoscale box unchecked.
Plot data during run
Select a specific plot configurator.
Duration for single animation loop, in seconds.
Animation frame rate (hz). Faster processors and smaller datasets allow faster frame rates. Frames may be dropped if rate is too high.
Direction of animation.
When checked, animation will loop until manually stopped.
Type of plot
Check box to show legend. Uncheck box to hide legend.
Choose a curve number designation before choosing data source and expression to plot.
Choose axis for the controls to the right: Logarithmic or Linear scaling, Autoscale or user selected scale.
Choose check box to show curve. Choose Uncheck box to hide curve.

Select the plot item from the corresponding data source or enter the name manually. Can also plot expressions of plot model variables, e.g. abs(sin(A+t)). Expressions involving datasets are NOT evaluated.

Choose the horizontal plot axis expression. Select the plot item from the corresponding data source or enter the name manually. Can also plot expressions of plot model variables, e.g. abs(sin(A+t)). Expressions involving datasets are NOT evaluated.
Choose the color of the item plotted.
Choose the shape of the plot symbol. Select blank for no symbol.
Choose the size of the plot symbol.
Choose plot line texture solid, dashed, or no line.
Source of the data to be plotted, e.g., model, tac file dataset, dataset, etc.
Set controls for the horizontal axis.
Set controls for the vertical axis.
Curve 1
Curve 2
Curve 3
Curve etc.
Plot data during run as it becomes available.
Plot data when run is finished.
Display configurator for plot 1
Display configurator for plot 2
Display configurator for plot 3
Display configurator for plot 4
Display configurator for plot 5
Display configurator for plot 6
Display configurator for plot 7
Display configurator for plot 8
Display configurator for plot 9
Display configurator for plot 10
Display configurator for plot 11
Display configurator for plot 12
Display configurator for plot 13
Display configurator for plot 14
Display configurator for plot 15
Display configurator for plot 16
Run animation from minimum to maximum value.
Run animation from maximum to minimum value.
X vs. Y
3D plot in two dimensions
3D plot in two dimensions
3D plot rendered as wire mesh
Manage appearance preferences.
Help on how to use JSim.
Manage graph appearance options.
Plot zoom control.
Number of plot rows in this page.
Number of plot columns in this page.
File export options for this dataset.
Export all curves in this dataset to an external file.
Export selected data curves only to an external file.
Manage curve names and content. Cut/copy/paste allows copying of curves between different datasets.
Put selected curves in copy buffer and remove from this dataset.
Copy selected curves to buffer for use by paste.
Paste curve in copy buffer into this dataset.
Rename selected curves.
Pop up filter options dialog to modify selected curves.
What type of filter?
Crop curve domain at low and high ends.
Resample curve over new regular domain.
Block filter is not yet available.
Normal filter is not yet available.
Low-end domain cutoff.
High-end domain cutoff.
Resampled domain delta.
Configurator allows you to modify data to be plotted.
Configurator controls what data is to be placed in the page and how it is to be rendered.
Rule allows vertical visual alignment within or between plots.
Rule allows horizontal alignment within or between plots.
Slider allows quick scrolling throught large data sets, including an option for animated scrolling.
Plot title visibility control.
Plot legend visibility control.
Plot X-axis label visibility control.
Plot Y-axis visibility control.
Plot footer visibility control.
Set all axes of current plot to autoscale.
Zoom out to previous plot axis ranges.
Zoom in to previous plot axis ranges.
Create new empty data set within this project. Curves may then be pasted into it from other data sets using the data set "Edit" menu.
Make all the fonts bigger for easier reading.
Make all the fonts smaller to conserve screen real estate.
Save current preferences for use in next JSim session by this user. Preferences are stored separately for each computer user. They are not stored in project files.
The default JSim light blue background.
For those who prefer the undersea JSim experience.
Harkens back to the Emerald Isle and the wee people.
Said to be soothing for prison and asylum inmates.
Roses are red, Violet is JSim...
The light and fruity JSim experience.
For the terminally dull.
Fine-tune your JSim background color.
Manage the parameter sets associated with this model.
Load the values from an existing project parameter set into this model.
Import parameter values from an external, legacy XSim paramater set (*.par) into this model.
Set all model parameters back to their compiled-in default values.

item.name: action$GModel$Forward ODE ICs from last run

JSimHelp.item: Set the initial condition variables for ODE variables to the final values for those variables from the last run. Multi-dimensional variables and variables whose initial conditions that are calculated from other variables are not affected.
Store the current parameter values for this model in the current parameter set (if any), or in a new one (if not).
Store the current parameter values for this model in a new project parameter set.
Control which page of model parameters is currently displayed.
A page showing all model inputs and output variables.
Controls settings for JSim's internal ODE/PDE solvers, if relevant.
Return to previously visited model parameter page.
Go to the next model parameter page in sequence.
Run the model once. Model output data will not be available until a model is run.
Other types of model runs.
Run the model multiple time based on the configuration in the model Loops tab.
Run JSim's model parameter optimizer based on the configuration set in the model's Optimizer tab.
Run JSim sensitivity analysis based on the configuration in this model's Sensitivity tab. Once run, plot variables of the form u@v, where v in a sensitivity variable, will be displayable.
Allows print and export of text in this page.
Export the page text to a external file.
Print the page text on a printer.
Text searching functions.
Go to a requested line number.
Find a requested word or phrase in the page text.
Repeat the previous find operation.
Select which information to view in this page.
Turn loops on or off.
Turn this loop off.
Turn this loop on, and perform the number of loops explicity set by the user.

Turn this loop on and automatically calculate the number of loops to perform based on the "Other Values" column. If the number of loops can't be calculated automatically, use the user-entered number of times.
Number of loops to perform.
Paramter to vary during this loop. The first run will use the value in the Start column. Subsequent runs will use values from the "Other Values" column.

Values to loop over for this parameter. This column may either contain a comma-separated list of fixed values, or the expressions "@+N", "@-N", "@*N" or "@/N" where N is a number. In the latter case, the parameter's value will be arithmetically re-adjusted for each run.

Parameter to run sensitivity analysis on. A sensitivity run runs the model once for the current parameter settings, and once for each variable in in this column. Once a sensitivity run is complete, users may plot data of the form u:v when u is a any model variable and v is a variable from this column.
This delta value will be added to the parameter's current value during the relevant model run.
Which optimization algorithm to use.
Simplex is a long-establish optimization that required minimum and maximum bounds be specified before the run.

GGopt is an unbound optimization algorithm that does not require minimum or maximum bounds be set before the run. Consequently, the values tested may cause some sensitive models to return non-sensical results.
The maximum number of model runs to call during this optimization.
Optimization will stop if the RMS error between model outputs and reference data becomes less than this amount.
Optimization will stop once the algorithm starts adjust parameter values by less than this amount.
The optimizer will stop if the number of iterations exceeds this number. The number of model runs in an iteration varies depending upon setup.
The optimization will stop if the gradient becomes less than this amount.
The optimization will stop if the relative error becomes less than this amount.
Parameter to vary in seeking the best data fit.
Initial step size for this parameter.

Data set containing reference data curve to match to model output. If this column shows "???", that means there are no datasets currently in the project and you will need to create some before you can proceed further with optimization. You may import data sets from external files in the Project tab "Add" menu, or store model data in a project data set from a plot page "File" menu.
Specifies the name of the data curve (within the data set on the left) to match to the model outputs during optimization.
Specifies the model output (or expression) to match to the data curve (on the left) during optimization.
This page is slated for revamping, so is not documented at this time.
Export and print options for this Parameter set.

Export the page text to an external file. Note there is no corresponding import function. If you wish to copy a parameter set to another project, use the cut/copy/paste options in the Project tab Edit menu to accomplish this.
Print the page text.
A project parameter set, containing parameters names and values pertaining to one or more models. Parameters comprise model input variables, function generator parameters and numeric solver settings.
System units file (nsrunit.mod) contains definitions for many common physical units used in models.
Plan text is a concise summary of the JSim planner output. It is intended primarily for JSim internals developers, but may also be used by users to get a sense for the order of model calculations.
MML text is the original model source code in JSim's Mathematical Modeling Language.
Flat MML text MML with all BCL (and other) templates expanded to their mathematical form. Flat MML is available if a model uses such templates.
Java text is the translation of the model source into executable java code. This is primarily of use to JSim internals developers.
Set # to 1.
Set # to 2.
Set # to 3.
Set # to 4.
Import/export/print model source code.
Import model source from external .mod file, erasing previous contents.
Insert additional model source code from external .mod file into the existing source code.
Export model source code to file.
Print model source code.
Compile the model. A model must be compiled before it can be run. If the compile is successful, the model Run Time tab will be pushed forward.
Model source code editor & compiler.
Access to model run-time parameters and single run control.
Information for model developers, including pre-defined physical units.
Configuration and run-time control for model loops, allowing model runs with varying parameter values to be compared.
Sensitivity analysis allows modelers to quantify how infinitesimal changes in model parameters affect model outputs.
The optimizer allows you to automatically match model output to fixed reference data by varying selected parameters.
Allows modeler to customize the appearance of the Run Time tab. This page is scheduled for revamping, and is not futher documented.
Image set editor is not yet implemented.

Relative RMS point weights within this data curve. Expression may be constant (giving equals weights) for vary based upon model domains. For example, "exp(-t)" would give exponentially decaying weights to data points (assuming t is a model realDomain).
Relative curve RMS weights. This number has meaning only if multiple reference curves are selected.

Create new function generator for this model, whose values may then be assigned to one or more dynamical model input variables. Function generators may represent abstract mathematical functions or sampled data from project data sets.
Controls which ODE solver algorithm is used for all model ODE calculcations.
Dopri5 is used initially. If the problem is very stiff causing Dopri5 to fail, Radau is used.
Dopri5 (Dorman and Prince) is an explicit Runge-Kutta method of order 5(4) for problems y'=f(x,y) with dense output of order 4.

Radau is an implicit Runge-Kutta method (Radau IIA) of variable order (switches automatically between orders 5, 9, and 13) for problems of the form My'=f(x,y) with possibly singular matrix M. Named for the french mathematician, R. Radau.
KM is the KUTTA-MERSON ODE solver implementing the Merson-modified Runge-Kutta method with adaptive steps.

Fehlberg is the Runge-Kutta Fehlberg adaptive stepsize algorithm. It adjusts the stepsize in such a way as to keep the absolute error in a step less than absolute tolerance and the fractional error less than relative tolerance.
Euler gives the solution at the next step, n+1, as y(n+1) = y(n) +h*f(x(n),y(n)) where h is the step size.
Runge-Kutta 4th order algorithm with fixed step size. The error is 5th order.

CVode uses variable order and variable step size methods: backward differentiation formulas (BDF) for stiff systems; Implicit Adams for nonstiff systems. For stiff problems uses explicit predictor with implicit corrector.
Controls which PDE solver algorithm is used for all model PDE calculations.

LSFEA (Lagrangian sliding fluid element) PDE solver solves parabolic PDE's in 1 space dimension by the method of time splitting advection, radial exchange and conversion, and diffusion are solved in sequential order in each time step.
An algorithm for solving time-dependent (parabolic) PDEs in 1 space dimension. It uses adaptive techniques to deal with rapid spatial variations.
Chebyshev polynomial software for elliptic-parabolic systems of PDEs.
Load/save/modify parameter set(s) associated with this model.
Import RTML (Run-time markup language) for customizing model run-time page appearance.
Export RTML (Run-time markup language) for customized menus & pages for external edit and reimport.
Export RTML (Run-time markup language) for default model run-time appearance. Useful as template for customized RTML.
2nd order finite difference method with optional flux-corrected transport for hyperbolic and parabolic equations
Use flux-corrected transport?
Initial "temperature" for simulated annealing algorithm. Temperature cools as algorithm proceeds, reducing random fluxuations. Temperature here has no physical meaning (e.g. Celsius).
Number of grid divisions per parameter. Grid search algorithm is most efficient when this number is odd.
Calculate covariance matrix and parameter confidence limits after optimization completes. This takes several additional model run to complete, and so should be disabled when not needed.
Random number seed, affecting values returned by MML random() function. A positive value returns a repeatable sequence each model run. A negative or zero values returns a new sequence each model run.
Maximum time for compilation, in seconds.
Maximum size of implicit equation solver block. Supported only in version 1.7.00 and above.
Initialize variable caches to NaN before model run?
Abort run if NaN's calculated in any model variable.
Print trace messages if NaN's calculated in any model variables. (Supported by local server only).
Comma separated list of variables to trace. Trace messages printed on console as model run proceeds. (Supported by local server only).
Ignore all variable overspecified messages from compiler. Supported only in version 1.7.00 and above.
Ignore all variable underspecified messages. Supported only in version 1.7.00 and above.

RK2, also known as modified trapezoid or Heun method gives the solution at the next step, n+1, as y(n+1) = y(n) + h/2*(f1 + f2) where f1 and f2 are defined as f1 = f(x(n), y(n)) f2 = f(x(n)+h, y(n)+h*f1) and h is the step size.

The area of the PDF function. If less than or equal to zero, it is defaulted to a value of 1. Formally it is the integral from start time (usually take to be zero) to infinity of PDF(t)*dt where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is a function of the independent variable. Area is used to scale the PDF so it is an appropriate model input. SPECIAL NOTE: The area will also be used to normalize the Longtail function after the PDF has been joined to the longtail.
Choice of PDF function for the first part of the Longtail function. Choices are LagNormal, Gaussian, Poisson, Random Walk, and Gamma variate.

The mean transit time of the PDF relative to the start time, t.min, where t is the independent realDomain variable. It is approximately the difference between the start time and when the peak of the PDF occurs. Formally, it is the integral from start time to infinity of PDF(t)*t*dt/area where t is the independent variable and PDF(t) is the PDF as a function of the independent variable. This is not the mean transit time of the longtail function. The mean transit time of the longtail function will usually be greater.

Relative dispersion of the PDF is the standard deviation of the PDF divided by the mean transit time. Formally, it is the square root of the integral from the start time (usually taken to be zero) to infinity (usually taken to be some large finite time) of PDF(t)*(t-tMean)*(t-tMean)*dt, all of which is divided by tMean. This is not the RD of the longtail function which is usually greater.
The skewness of the PDF. See caveats for setting skewness for the specific PDF you have selected. Gaussian and Poisson PDFs do not use this parameter.

>Choose either tJoin, the time where the the PDF will be joined by the longtail or frJoin, the fraction of the peak on the downslope where the PDF is joined. frJoin selects a specific time point for the cutoff and should not be used for optimization. Use tJoin instead.
The time where the the PDF is joined by either the sum of decaying exponentials or power law functions.
The fraction of the peak on the downslope side of the PDF where the PDF is joined by either the sum of decaying exponentials or power law functions. Use tJoin instead if optimizing.
Select either Exponential or Power Law for the type of longtail function desired.
Number of exponential functions used, from 1 to 4.
Relative magnitude of first exponential function. Not optimizable if nExp=1 because sum of exponentials is rescaled to match PDF and slope at joining location.
Relative magnitude of second exponential function. If nExp=2, optimize only on w2 and k2.
Relative magnitude of third exponential function. If nExp=3, optimize only on w2, w3, k2, and k3.
Relative magnitude of fourth exponential function. If nExp=3, optimize only on w2, w3, w4, k2, k3, and k4.
Relative magnitude of first exponential decay constant. Not optimizable if nExp=1 because k's are rescaled to match PDF and slope at joining location.
>Relative magnitude of second exponential decay constant. If nExp=2, optimize only on w2 and k2.
Relative magnitude of second exponential decay constant. If nExp=3, optimize only on w2, w3, k2, and k3.
Relative magnitude of second exponential decay constant. If nExp=3, optimize only on w2, w3, w4, k2, k3, and k4.
Number of power law functions used, from 1 to 4.
Relative magnitude of first power law function. Not optimizable if nPow=1 because sum of power laws is rescaled to match PDF and slope at joining location.
Relative magnitude of second power law function.
Relative magnitude of third power law function.
Relative magnitude of fourth power law function.
Absolute magnitude of first power law exponent.
Absolute magnitude of second power law exponent.
Absolute magnitude of third power law exponent.
Absolute magnitude of fourth power law exponent.
If not zero, the curve from time=0 to timeToRepeat is repeated every timeToRepeat interval. This parameter is used to generate a train of long tail pulses.
>Defines the fraction of the peak where the PDF is terminated and also where the Longtail function is terminated. Appropriate value is 1.0E-06).
Choice of Regular or Linear (early part of rise of PDF replaced by straight line. Used only if LagNormal PDF is selected.
When a parameter set is locked, attempts to replace it will result in a warning dialog.
